title: Sumas Mountain
text:
Sumas Mountain is a <a href="mountain">mountain</a> located in <a href="Whatcom%20County%2C%20Washington">Whatcom County</a>, <a href="Washington%20%28state%29">Washington</a>, 15 miles northeast of <a href="Bellingham%2C%20Washington">Bellingham</a> and southwest of <a href="Vedder%20Mountain">Vedder Mountain</a>. Located in the <a href="Skagit%20Range">Skagit Range</a>, the mountain is notable for its high <a href="biodiversity">biodiversity</a> and year-round <a href="hiking%20trail">hiking trail</a>s. It is sometimes referred to as American Sumas to distinguish it from an <a href="Sumas%20Mountain%20%28British%20Columbia%29">identically named mountain</a> across the <a href="Canada%E2%80%93United%20States%20border">Canada–United States border</a> in <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a> just to the north, both of which are drained by <a href="tributary">tributary</a> creeks of the <a href="Sumas%20River">Sumas River</a>.
The mountain is largely owned by the <a href="Washington%20Department%20of%20Natural%20Resources">Washington Department of Natural Resources</a>, but some parcels are privately held. While the public land is open for recreation, it is managed primarily for timber harvest. <a href="Clearcutting">Clearcuts</a> are present on many slopes and most all the remaining forest is in varying stages of recovery and regrowth.
<a href="Washington%20State%20Route%20547">Washington State Route 547</a>, which traverses a low pass on the mountain's northern flank, runs northwest from the <a href="Washington%20State%20Route%20542">Mount Baker Highway</a>, (SR 542) in <a href="Kendall%2C%20Washington">Kendall</a> to <a href="Washington%20State%20Route%209">SR 9</a> in <a href="Sumas%2C%20Washington">Sumas</a>, which is located on the Canada–United States border and south of <a href="Abbotsford%2C%20British%20Columbia">Abbotsford</a>, <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a>. The <a href="Chicago%2C%20Milwaukee%2C%20St.%20Paul%20and%20Pacific%20Railroad">Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad</a> once traversed the same pass.
The controversial <a href="Swift%20Creek%20Landslide">Swift Creek Landslide</a> is located on the mountain's western slope.
